bmittking

This is the question her campaign and the whole Democratic party need to answer.
 
 Clinton has almost no chance of winning the nomination without causing a rift in the party, and she has an even smaller chance of winning in the general. 
 
 Recent polls say that almost half of all Americans have a negative opinion of her, and the Reverend Wright scandal seems to have hurt Obama less than Clinton's campaign has hurt her in the past weeks.
 
 The longer Hillary Clinton stays in the race, the less likely it is that the Democrats will win in November.

 The longer Hillary Clinton stays in the race, the less likely it is that the Democrats will win in November.

 It's plain selfish and stubborn as far as I'm concerned, I'm surprised that the Democratic party itself isn't stepping in, maybe they are behind the scenes.

The Clintons are a political machine. Hillary is a narcissist. She cares nothing for others except as they represent a potential vote to grant her the power she craves. She will likely not leave the race on her own...no matter what the polls say.

I can understand why Paul and even Huckabee were in the race for so long, because they were just trying to get their messages out. They didn't hurt the Republicans' chances of winning in November, and I think that McCain is a stronger candidate because of them.
 
 However, it is different with Hillary. People already know about her ideas, and all the voters who care about the policy differences between her and Obama already know them. This primary season is obviously not about policy, but instead about principals, experience, electability, and emotion.
 
 I would like a Clinton supporter to weigh in on this question.

 Are you of the opinion that distrust of white people equals racism? I am not.
What is your definition of racism? Do you distinguish between bigotry and racism? Is racism a form of bigotry?
sinjin

What is your definition of racism? Do you distinguish between bigotry and racism? Is racism a form of bigotry?

 
 Bigotry is prejudice associated with race in common usage.
 
 Racism is a belief in the ultimate superiority of a given race, usually one's own.
 
 They are related but not identical.
isly ilwott

Bigotry is prejudice associated with race in common usage.
 
 Racism is a belief in the ultimate superiority of a given race, usually one's own.
 
 They are related but not identical.
I differ slightly. Bigotry is not necessarily tied to race. Bigotry is when one is intolerantly devoted to his own church, party, belief or opinion and will not accept as valid any thought that conflicts with his. It does not have to be associated with race. It does not have to imply superiority except in correctness of thought.
 
 Racism is quite understandably related to race. Racism is the belief that race is the primary determinant of worth and that one race is superior to the other by way of heredity. I think bigotry and racism are related only in that they both require one party to be thought less valuable than the other. When the bigotry is applied to things others than race, there is no racism involved. Bigotry when applied to race becomes racism.

The white race has not been suppressed and relieved of rights and properties near as much as blacks, American Indians and Asians. I would suspect more resentment and hatred in their midst than among whites who have not experienced such things. This is not to say that they are no Christians in the other races...certainly there are many. I believe the history of how a race has been treated has much to do with the percentage of angry racists among them.
